body:
I can help with that.  I'll comment in more detail after reading the paper on Monday. 

@Edresson might be interested too as he works on something similar.

Sorry, I was busy on other projects but I have more time to work on this now. Have you read the paper @erogol ? Are you still interested ? If not, @Edresson maybe I can help on the similar thing that you are working on ?

Hi @WeberJulian ,

Sorry everything was very busy and I couldn't see it.

I read the article and really interesting. In addition to this article I would like to list the article [End-to-End Code-Switched TTS with Mix of Monolingual Recordings ](https://csttsdemo.github.io/).

In addition, the article: [One Model, Many Languages: Meta-learning for Multilingual Text-to-Speech](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2008.00768.pdf) combines the best of both approaches.

I believe that the best way is to implement this last article.

On this demo page you have the comparison of the three models trained under the same conditions: https://tomiinek.github.io/multilingual_speech_samples/

In addition, the [implementation](https://github.com/Tomiinek/Multilingual_Text_to_Speech) is open source (with the MIT license) which we can use as a basis for implementation in TTS (as done in GlowTTS).

I can do my best to help you with the implementation as it is very interesting for the community. In addition, we can try to propose some improvements to the method.
Sounds great ! I'm gonna take some time to read those articles/papers you shared and I'll get back to you.

@Edresson I listened to the samples from the [demo page](https://tomiinek.github.io/multilingual_speech_samples/) you shared and indeed the generated approach compares favorably to the fully shared and separated approaches. What bothers me is that [the samples](https://google.github.io/tacotron/publications/multilingual/index.html) from the authors of "Multilingual speech synthesis and cross-language voice cloning" sounds so much better than the one from the demo page that compares the approach.
What do you think explain the disparity ?
The team from google has a much better trained vocoder ?
They spend more time tunning the hyperparameters ?
Higher quality/length dataset ? (although google only use 3 ES and 5 CN speakers which is impressive) Common voice (used by generated) can be very noisy 
They cherry picked the samples ?
Bad implementation from the author of the demo page ?
But yeah the samples from the generated approach sound good to me, I'm gonna study the code and the paper to be sure that I understand how it works and how it could be implemented here.

> 
> 
> @Edresson I listened the sample from the [demo page](https://tomiinek.github.io/multilingual_speech_samples/) you shared and indeed the generated approach compares favorably to the fully shared and separated approaches. What bothers me is that [the samples](https://google.github.io/tacotron/publications/multilingual/index.html) from the authors of "Multilingual speech synthesis and cross-language voice cloning" sounds so much better than the one from the demo page that compares the approach.
> What do you think explain the disparity ?
> The team from google has a much better trained vocoder ?
> They spend more time tunning the hyperparameters ?
> Higher quality/length dataset ? (although google only use 3 ES and 5 CN speakers which is impressive) Common voice (used by generated) can be very noisy
> They cherry picked the samples ?
> Bad implementation from the author of the demo page ?

I believe it can be a mix of the various factors that you mentioned. The datasets used by Google should be of better quality. Hyperparameters can also be a problem. The interesting thing is that the comparison between the models is done in the same scenario (dataset, hyperparameters and the like), so there is a fairer comparison.
I've spent some time looking at the code and I don't know what a good first step would be ^^' I think I'm gonna try training a model with the original repo and mailabs to test it out.

In the paper, they say 

> To train code-switching models, multi-speaker data is required to disentangle the connection between languages and speakers

and they use it as a reason to use common voice in their dataset. I was wondering if instead of the "speaker classifier block" they use, we could use @mueller91's pretrained encoder. That way, we don't have to use common voice to increase speaker count and thus lower the quality of the generated voice. Do you think it could work/be useful @Edresson ?

EDIT: nevermind I think the classifier is important for the trainning of the encoder...

> The classifier follows principles of domain adversarial training [22] and is used to proactively remove speaker-specific information from the encoders.

> In the paper, they say
> 
> > To train code-switching models, multi-speaker data is required to disentangle the connection between languages and speakers
> 
> and they use it as a reason to use common voice in their dataset. I was wondering if instead of the "speaker classifier block" they use, we could use @mueller91's pretrained encoder. That way, we don't have to use common voice to increase speaker count and thus lower the quality of the generated voice. Do you think it could work/be useful @Edresson ?
> 
> EDIT: nevermind I think the classifier is important for the trainning of the encoder...
> 
> > The classifier follows principles of domain adversarial training [22] and is used to proactively remove speaker-specific information from the encoders.

I had thought about the future of using the speaker encoder instead of the speaker classifier block. However, as you mentioned, it is apparently important for encoder training. In the future we can think of some way to integrate, using the speaker encoder would bring many advantages.
